title: Making transparency work for you
body: This introductory module examines the benefits of publishing open data for local authorities. Below we will learn about open data release can help you save time, imrpove services and save money, how to publish a dataset under an open licence and case studies of how open data created positive impact in local authorities.

title: What is open data and why should we publish it?
displayTitle: What is open data and why should we publish it?
body:
Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share.

Local authorities has been releasing open data for years on everything from election results to the locations of public toilets. Publishing open data can have a range of benefits for your authority. But what are the best arguements to persuade your colleages and leadership?
instruction: Click on each of the boxes below to expand.

_items.title: The case for economic benefit
_items.body:
To support the emergence of new data-driven businesses and the growth of existing ones, local authorities need to publish key datasets.

In return, authorities are seeing the benefit of local data economies that attractive investment, increase employment and deliver new value to the area.

_items.title: The case for improved services
_items.body:
Authorities need to balance the demands of growing populations with the need to tackle small-scale, local issues. In an era of unprecedented strain on local budgets, open data offers an opportunity to improve the quality of local services without the outlay of full service delivery by allowing creative people to build their own solutions.

The availability of detailed open data is essential to enabling new services at the local level.

_items.title: The case for transparency
_items.body: Open data has become a key component of authorities' transparency work. Releases are also helping to make council operations simpler to understand and reducing the burden of FoI requests in popular areas such as spending and senior salaries.

_items.title: The case for innovation
_items.body:
By growing economies, improving services and building greater transparency, open data allows authorities to idenfity additional savings in key areas, such as healthcare, education and utilities.

Open data helped reveal a £200 million potential saving for the health service and can highlight similar efficiencies at the local level.

title: What about the costs of publication?
displayTitle: What about the costs of publication?
body:
Open data is usually free at the point of use.

The traditional justification for this free service has been that authorities produce their open data through the operation of taxpayer-funded services.

However, gathering and maintaining data always has a cost attached to it. For this reason, in some cases local authorities may need to charge the user a small fee to cover any costs associated with the data. For this data to qualify as open, the cost should be no more than the 'reasonable reproduction cost' of the data involved. Authorities can charge a fee to cover the costs of supporting a user's data request but should not charge a premium for the data.

title: How to publish your dataset: The basics
displayTitle: How to publish your dataset: The basics
body: Follow the three steps below to publish your dataset online.
instruction: Click on each of the boxes below to expand.

_items.title: 1. Describe your data well
_items.body: Think carefully about how you describe your dataset on your webpage. Consider in particular the title and description of your dataset. Will the audience understand your title? Is it what would be searched for? Do you need tags and subtitles? Have you described how the dataset it supported and how old data is accessed? Creating good 'metadata' is the first step to publishing a strong dataset.

_items.title: 2. Publish the data
_items.body: Put the data online in a place which is easily accessible and referencable from other places like catalogues and other websites. Your data also needs to be directly accessible to a machine and should not require the acceptance of any terms and conditions terms and conditions.

_items.title: 3. Validate the dataset
_items.body:
Check that you dataset meets the minimum standards for quality and usability. The LGA has a quick validation tool that lets you check whether your data matches the quality and consistency guidelines of the DCLG transparency code.
Take me to the LGA Validator.

title: How to publish your dataset: The licence
displayTitle: How to publish your dataset: The licence
body:
Once you know your dataset is published online, the most important thing is to place it under the correct licence. The licence is the only thing that can make your published data into open data. While local authorities can choose the licence they place on their dataset, we strongly recommend using the Open Government Licence (OGL) for all of your data. OGL is a simple, clear licence used by all government departments and many others. Placing one on your dataset takes only a few minutes. To apply your licence follow the link below.
Take me to the OGL page.

title: The benefits of publishing open data - Local authority case studies
displayTitle: The benefits of publishing open data - Local authority case studies
body: Publishing open data can provide authorities with a range of benefits. Below you can explore the main benefits together with some examples.
instruction: Click the forward arrow for more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

_items.title: Support growing economies
_items.body:
To support the emergence of new data-driven businesses and the growth of existing ones, authorities are publishing key datasets to support local data economies.

In return, local governments are reaping the benefits of a growing data economy as in Leeds, where the 'Data Mill' platform has attracted more than 250 registered users including new businesses in tourism, schools and waste collection.

_items.title: Improved service delivery
_items.body:
Local authorities need to balance the demands of austerity with the need to tackle small-scale, local issues. In the absense of significant funding for non-frontline services, many authorities are using open data to improve the efficiency of their delivery.

The availability of detailed open data can improve delivery of services at the local level.

One example of this improved service delivery is the tourism initiative implemented by North Somerset council, who used open data to enable the production of a new website supporting the regional tourist economy
Take me to North Somerset case study

_items.title: Cost savings
_items.body:
By growing economies and improving services, open data allows local governments to make savings in key areas, like response to FoI requests and energy use.

In Windsor & Maidenhead council, real-time open data helped reduce energy spending in council buildings by 16%

In Carlisle, publication of real-time business rates has to significantly reduce Freedom of Information requests and is saving the council up to £15000 annually.

_items.title: Better public perception
_items.body:
Authorities have the opportunity to improve their public perception and dialogue through the release of open data.

Open data helps support transparency and also has the potential to increase favourable press coverage through a growing number of data journalists.

Norfolk council is among those improving transparency around procurement processes through the release of
contract pipeline data

title: Are you ready to make transparency work for you?
displayTitle: Are you ready to make transparency work for you?
body: Can you recall these four things about publishing open data.

title: Cases for publishing open data

title: Cost savings from open data
body: Which of the case studies below is NOT a real example of cost savings from open data?

_items.text: Windsor & Maidenhead save 16% on energy consumption in their buildings
Carisle save up to £15000 per year on business rates FoI request
Perthshire increase bus service effiency by 24%

That’s right!

title: The benefits of open data publication
displayTitle: The benefits of open data publication
body:
Local authorities can access a range of benefits from publishing open data including cost savings on essential services, creation of local business hubs and better relationships with the public. In our next module we will examine the importance of publishing in consistent ways and how the LGA standards can make publishing simple and maximise results
